raw_text:
Markets signal Brazilian recovery
 
 The Brazilian stock market has risen to a record high as investors display growing confidence in the durability of the country's economic recovery.
 
 The main Bovespa index on the Sao Paolo Stock Exchange closed at 24,997 points on Friday, topping the previous record market close reached the previous day. The market's buoyancy reflects optimism about the Brazilian economy, which could grow by as much as 4.5% in 2004. Brazil is recovering from last year's recession - its worst in a decade.
 
 Economic output declined 0.2% in 2003 and President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva - elected as Brazil's first working-class president in 2002 - was strongly criticised for pursuing a hardline economic policy.
 
 Investors have praised his handling of the economy as foreign investment has risen, unemployment has fallen and inflation has been brought under control. Analysts believe the stock market will rise above the 25,000 mark for the first time before too long. "There should be more space for gains until the end of the year, somewhere up to 27,000 points," said Paschoal Tadeu Buonomo, head of equities trading at brokers TOV. Brazil's currency, the real, also rose to its highest level against the dollar in more than two years on Friday. Although interest rates still stand at a punitive 17.25%, inflation has fallen from 9% to 7% while exports are booming, particularly of agricultural products. "For the first time in decades, we have all three economic policy pillars in line during a recovery," Finance Minister Antonio Palocci told the Associated Press news agency. "Government accounts are in surplus, we have a current account surplus and inflation is under control."
 
 Investors were deeply suspicious of President da Silva, a former trade union leader who campaigned on a programme of extensive land redistribution and a large rise in the minimum wage. However, Mr da Silva has stuck to an orthodox monetary policy inherited from his predecessor even in the face of last year's economic crisis. This has earned him the disapproval of rural farm workers, thousands of whom who took to the streets of Brasilia on Thursday to protest against government policies. President da Silva has defended his policies, arguing that Brazil cannot afford to continue the cycle of boom and bust which afflicted it in recent decades.
llama3.2:1b: Brazil's stock market has reached a record high due to growing investor confidence in the country's economic recovery. The main Bovespa index closed at 24,997 points on Friday, topping previous records. Analysts expect the market to rise above 25,000 before the end of the year.
llama3.2:3b: The Brazilian stock market reached a record high, with the Bovespa index closing at 24,997 points, driven by growing confidence in the country's economic recovery, led by President Lula da Silva's policies, including an orthodox monetary policy and control of inflation.
gemma2:2b: The Brazilian stock market reached a record high due to investor confidence in the country's economic recovery. The economy is expected to grow by 4.5% in 2004 after recovering from a severe recession in 2003.  President Lula da Silva’s handling of the economy, including control over inflation and unemployment, has led to increased foreign investment and positive market performance.  The Brazilian real also reached its highest level against the dollar in years.  Despite challenges from rural workers protesting against certain government policies, Brazil's economic policy is currently in alignment with a sustainable recovery.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Key points:
- Brazilian stock market rises to record high
- Optimistic economic outlook with 4.5% growth potential
- Economic output declines by 0.2%
- Foreign investment, unemployment, inflation rise
- Real's value has risen to 27,000
- President Lula da Silva faces criticism for his economic policies
- Real is at its highest level since 2001
- Government accounts surplus, current account surplus, and inflation under control
qwen2.5:1.5b: The Brazilian stock market has reached a record high as investors show increasing confidence in the country's economic recovery from last year's recession. Growth is expected to exceed 4.5% in 2004, with foreign investment rising and unemployment decreasing under President Lula's reformative but economically conservative administration. This positive development reflects improved fiscal and monetary policies aimed at stabilizing inflation and boosting exports of agricultural products.
qwen2.5:3b: The Brazilian stock market reached a record high as investors gain confidence in economic recovery following last year's recession. The main Bovespa index closed at 24,997 points on Friday, with growth projections of up to 4.5% for 2004 expected. President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva has handled the economy well, leading to foreign investment increases and unemployment decreases. Analysts predict further gains above 25,000 points before year-end. The real currency reached its highest level against the dollar in over two years. Despite concerns from farm workers about land redistribution policies, inflation is under control and government accounts are surplus.
opencoder:1.5b: The Brazilian stock market has risen to a record high as investors display growing confidence in the durability of the country's economic recovery. The main Bovespa index on the Sao Paolo Stock Exchange closed at 24,997 points on Friday, topping the previous record market close reached the previous day. Brazil is recovering from last year's recession - its worst in a decade. Investors have praised his handling of the economy as foreign investment has risen, unemployment has fallen and inflation has been brought under control. However, interest rates still stand at a punitive 17.25%, inflation has fallen from 9% to 7%. The Brazilian currency, the real, also rose to its highest level against the dollar in more than two years on Friday. Nonetheless, investors were deeply suspicious of President da Silva who campaigned on extensive land redistribution and a large rise in the minimum wage. However, he has remained orthodox monetary policy even amidst the backdrop of the economic crisis.
smollm:1.7b:
The Brazilian stock market has risen to a record high as investors display growing confidence in the durability of the country's economic recovery. The main Bovespa index on the Sao Paolo Stock Exchange closed at 24,997 points on Friday, topping the previous record market close reached the previous day. The market's buoyancy reflects optimism about the Brazilian economy, which could grow by as much as 4.5% in 2004. Brazil is recovering from last year's recession - its worst in a decade.

Economic output declined 0.2% in 2003 and President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva - elected as Brazil's first working-class president in 2002 - was strongly criticized for pursuing a hardline economic policy. Analysts believe the stock market will rise above the 25,000 mark for the first time before too long. "There should be more space for gains until the end of the year, somewhere up to 27,000 points," said Paschoal Tadeu Buonomo, head of equities trading at brokers TOV. Brazil's currency, the real, also rose to its highest level against the dollar in more than two years on Friday. Although interest rates still stand at a punitive 17.25%, inflation has fallen from 9% to 7% while exports are booming, particularly of agricultural products. "For the first time in decades, we have all three economic policy pillars in line during a recovery," Finance Minister Antonio Palocci told the Associated Press news agency. "Government accounts are in surplus, we have a current account surplus and inflation is under control."

Investors were deeply suspicious of President da Silva, a former trade union leader who campaigned on an orthodox monetary policy inherited from his predecessor even in the face of last year's economic crisis. Mr da Silva has defended his policies, arguing that Brazil cannot afford to continue the cycle of boom and bust which afflicted it in recent decades. "We need to be careful not to repeat the mistakes of the past," he said in a statement. "The economy is recovering but we must ensure that this recovery is sustainable."

Brazil's economic recovery has been slow, with growth averaging 0.5% per annum over the past two years. The country's main trading partners are China and the United States, which account for around 40% of its exports. However, Brazil's economy remains heavily dependent on commodities such as soybeans, iron ore and oil, which account for around 60% of its exports.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Alright, I need to summarize this text. Let me read through each sentence carefully.

The first paragraph talks about the Brazilian stock market rising as investors show confidence. The main index closed at a record high. Then it mentions economic recovery but notes some criticism from the government.

Economic output was down by 0.2%, and the president faced backlash for his economic policies, especially regarding land redistribution and minimum wage.

Investors are optimistic about the economy, supported by rising foreign investment, lower unemployment, and controlled inflation. The real currency has appreciated more than twice in two years. There's also mention of a surplus in government accounts, a current account surplus, and inflation control.

However, there's skepticism from rural workers who were protesting against government policies. Despite his criticism, the president maintains an unconventional monetary policy due to last year's crisis.

Now, I need to condense all this into a concise summary while keeping key points: market rise, economic recovery with some criticism, investor optimism, specific economic indicators, and context about rural workers.
</think>

The Brazilian stock market has risen, reaching a record high as investors show confidence in the economy's recovery. The main Bovespa index on the Sao Paolo Stock Exchange closed at a new high, reflecting optimism about growth potential. Economic output declined 0.2% in 2003, but President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, former Trade Union leader, faced backlash for his policies and criticism from rural workers. Investors expect economic recovery despite skepticism, with rising foreign investment, lower unemployment, and controlled inflation, supported by a strong real currency.
tinyllama:1.1b: Markets signal Brazilian recovery by reaching a record high as investors express confidence in the durability of the country's economic recovery. The main Bovespa index on the Sao Paolo Stock Exchange has risen to a record level, with optimism about the country's economy, which could grow by 4.5%, reflected in the market's buoyant tone. This is supported by President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva's handling of the economy, which has seen foreign investment and job creation, as well as a decline in inflation. However, interest rates remain punitive, and there is still a chance for further gains until the end of the year, with the real rising against the dollar to its highest level since 2016. Investors' pessimism regarding President da Silva's policies remains, with protests by rural farm workers on Thursday calling for his resignation. The markets' optimistic outlook has earned praise from foreign investors who believe that Brazil can avoid the cycle of boom and bust afflicting it in recent decades.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The stock market in Brazil has seen a significant rise, reflecting optimism about the country's economic recovery. Investors have displayed renewed confidence in the strength of the Brazilian economy, after having witnessed its worst recession since 1984 last year. As a result, the Bovespa index on the Sao Paulo Stock Exchange has reached a record high of 24,997 points on Friday, marking an increase of 0.5% compared to its previous record closing value. This bounce in Brazil's stock market could signal a more optimistic outlook for the country's economy, as investors are anticipating further growth and job opportunities ahead.
phi:2.7b: The Brazilian stock market closed at a record high as investors showed confidence in the country's economic recovery. Economic output declined last year but is expected to grow by 4.5% this year. Investors praise President da Silva for his handling of the economy, leading to rising foreign investment, falling unemployment and under control inflation. Despite criticism from some farmers who protested against government policies, the president has adhered to an orthodox monetary policy.
orca-mini:3b: The Brazilian stock market has risen to a record high as investors display growing confidence in the country's economic recovery, with output declining 0.2% in 2003 and President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva pursuing an orthodox monetary policy. Foreign investment has risen, unemployment has fallen and inflation has been brought under control, while exports are booming, particularly of agricultural products. Investors believe that the stock market will rise above the 25,000 mark for the first time before too long, and the real has also reached its highest level against the dollar in more than two years. Despite high interest rates, inflation has fallen from 9% to 7% while exports are booming, particularly of agricultural products.
hermes3:3b: Brazilian stock market reaches record high as investors show confidence in economic recovery from last year's recession. Market buoyancy reflects growth up to 4.5% for 2004, lower inflation, controlled unemployment, and surplus government accounts.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: The Brazilian stock market reached a record high, fueled by growing investor confidence in the country's economic recovery. Brazil is recovering from its worst recession in 10 years, with economic output declining 0.2% in 2003. President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva's handling of the economy has been praised as foreign investment rose, unemployment fell, and inflation was brought under control. Analysts predict the stock market will rise above 25,000 points by year-end. The real, Brazil's currency, also reached its highest level against the dollar in over two years.
chatgpt-4o-latest: The Brazilian stock market has reached a record high, reflecting investor confidence in the country's economic recovery. The Bovespa index closed at 24,997 points, with expectations of further gains. Brazil's economy, recovering from a recession in 2003, is projected to grow by 4.5% in 2004. President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, initially criticized for his strict economic policies, has gained investor approval as foreign investment rises, unemployment falls, and inflation is controlled. The real has strengthened against the dollar, and exports, especially in agriculture, are booming. Despite high interest rates, Brazil has achieved a surplus in government accounts and the current account. While da Silva's adherence to orthodox monetary policies has reassured investors, it has sparked protests from rural workers. He defends his approach, emphasizing the need to break Brazil's cycle of economic instability.
stablelm2:1.6b: The Brazilian stock market has reached a record high due to growing confidence in the country's economic recovery, despite ongoing recession. Output declined 0.2% in 2013 but President Lula da Silva, who was elected as Brazil's first working-class president, improved his handling of the economy with falling unemployment and inflation, leading to foreign investment rise. Analysts believe the stock market could surpass its previous record by end-2014.
granite3.1-dense:2b: The Brazilian stock market reached a record high on Friday, signalling investors' growing confidence in the country's economic recovery from its worst recession in a decade (2003, -0.2%). President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, elected in 2002 as Brazil's first working-class president, has implemented an orthodox monetary policy, praised for bringing inflation down from 9% to 7%, controlling it at 17.25%, and maintaining government surplus. Despite criticism for his hardline stance on economic issues like land redistribution and minimum wage increases, da Silva's policies have drawn foreign investment and reduced unemployment. Analysts predict the Bovespa index could exceed 27,000 points by year-end. The real also hit its highest level against the dollar in over two years. Rural farm workers protested against government policies on Thursday, but da Silva defends his approach to avoid another boom-bust cycle.
reference: Investors have praised his handling of the economy as foreign investment has risen, unemployment has fallen and inflation has been brought under control.The Brazilian stock market has risen to a record high as investors display growing confidence in the durability of the country's economic recovery.However, Mr da Silva has stuck to an orthodox monetary policy inherited from his predecessor even in the face of last year's economic crisis.President da Silva has defended his policies, arguing that Brazil cannot afford to continue the cycle of boom and bust which afflicted it in recent decades.Economic output declined 0.2% in 2003 and President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva - elected as Brazil's first working-class president in 2002 - was strongly criticised for pursuing a hardline economic policy.Analysts believe the stock market will rise above the 25,000 mark for the first time before too long.Although interest rates still stand at a punitive 17.25%, inflation has fallen from 9% to 7% while exports are booming, particularly of agricultural products.
